text: There's something so hilarious about Jordan Peterson's livestreams getting frustrated at being spammed with "Address the Jewish question!"

replies.author: @sedosk-akritai
replies.text:
Know whats even more hilarious?: leftists getting frustrated for never managing to properly, through any substantive means, articulate the claim that JP is in any way morally, prescriptively or pragmatically the equivalent, or the adjacent, of the far right or the National Socialists. Seems like they can only beg the question or point out ridiculous non sequitur such as what other people asked him about half a dozen times in his hundreds of lectures and interviews that spam for more than a decade, even before he got famous.


And in that regard, 3 Arrows' entire attempt at doing exactly that, at the end, is absolute evidence of his limitless stupidity: "Peterson criticizes an ideology that is ruining society. The Nazis criticised an ideology that they thought ruined society. Ergo Peterson Nazi". Its nothing short of that low IQ mental gymnastic.





Its propagandistic. Nazis criticized an entire demographic, and tied to it a false ideological premise (something the wokes do all the time against certain demographics, but someone like Peterson never does that, as he explicitly denounces "identity politics", he criticizes positions, not tying them to identities of demographics).



Also, lets not forget that communists and progressives like 3 arrows also have their equivalent of the "jews" = the rich (but if we go to cultural marxism territory, then it can be the whites, the males, the cis, the colonizer, etc.). 3 Arrow's criticism is empty and can be applied to himself or pretty much to any ideological position that stands to have any opposition to any other ideological group. Its actually worse since wokeism notoriously presupposes biases and malice to people based on gender, race, etc. (CRT is a clear example of this). 

Another cardinal difference being ignored is how Peterson can demonstrate how what he criticizes 1) exists and 2) is wrong. The Nazis never managed to demonstrate the existance of anything they called "jewish bolshevism". 



And lets not forget: 3 arrows' greatest dishonesty here in equating Peterson to "nazi" is in that Peterson's approach to solving societal issues is through debate, dialogue, scientific enquiry, and a fair treatment, without coercion, for all involved. This was not the Nazi way. 3 Arrows' side however is very quick (and intellectually weak) to proptly call for the use of force or a means of cancellation against their ideological opponents, much like the Nazis. 3 Arrows is closer to the Nazis than Peterson could ever be, his cherrypicking notwithstanding.

replies.author: @Dusty1698
replies.text:
â€‹@sedosk-akritai Your rampant use of whataboutism to criticize this video as well as your flagrant misinterpretation of the intentions behind it is unfortunate.

3 Arrows explicitly states at the end that he doesn't believe JP to be a fascist or a Nazi. He simply claims him to be grossly ignorant of the history of the Nazi ideology, namely that JP misunderstands the logical progression of Nazism as something that's simply "evil". Sure, to you or I, it was evil, but to Hitler, it was simply an application of logic, and this distinction is critical. 

Also, he didn't show folks asking JP to "address the Jewish question" in order to imply that JP himself is sympathetic to Nazism, but to highlight that the way in which he misconstrues the nature of the Nazi ideology invites folks who are sympathetic to Nazism to inquire further about the matter.

replies.author: @danopticon
replies.text:
â @KyussTheWalkingWorm- Peterson is even a pretty bad source for info on Jung.

He does with Jung what he does with everything: he cherry-picks the bits he imagines support his diatribe-du-jour (bearing in mind that, as an opportunist, Peterson contradicts himself frequently, depending on what drugs heâ€™s consumed for breakfast and who he has beef with that day), then he pounds those bits beyond recognition into a shape suiting his ends, and then he discards the big bits contradicting him.

But despite Peterson, Jungâ€™s writing has proven useful to us, both in social science and in psychology â€¦ albeit, in heavily-modified form. (It has after all been over 100 years since Jung first set pen to paper.)

Archetypes may have no literal, palpable reality (a fact to which Peterson seems oblivious), but theyâ€™re a useful early conceptualization of what we might now call cultural tropes, personal narratives anchored in cultural tropes, socially-constructed identities, and so much more. Today we still employ these notions in untangling peopleâ€™s behavior, whether individually or as a group.

It would be wrong to take Jung as the final authority on anything without first reading all thatâ€™s been written about his work in the intervening decades, but it would also be wrong to discount him entirely just on account of some quack taking a shine to him. So please donâ€™t let Peterson sour you on Jung.

Jung is deeply problematic â€” he was deeply anti-Semitic, for one thing â€” and he got most of the details and even some of the fundamentals catastrophically wrong â€¦ but, like the equally-problematic Freud, in the broad strokes he was onto something, and there is a lot which can be salvaged from his work and put to use today.

replies.author: @robmartino1461
replies.text: @Niko0902 Actually the main problem for the Nazi war economy was not lack of manpower. They acquired tons of that by forcibly relocating civilians from all over their occupied territories into the industrial areas of Germany. Their problem was a lack of resources (oil and oil products being the most prominent, but not by any means only). This severely limited the production capacity of Germany even after it tried a total mobilization of all labour after 1943. I mean even though they in  theory controlled the industrial and human assets of most of continental Europe Germany was outproduced not only by the USSR and the USA but even Great Britain! So even if the Nazis had considered exploiting the concentration camp population primarily for production (and not seen hard labour as yet another means of extermination) it wouldn't really have yielded significant results. As with so many things that Peterson like's to authoritatively hang his arguments around, the truth is a bit more complicated.

replies.author: @A-Duck
replies.text:
â€‹@rezalustig6773 That's an entirely vapid counter, as it doesn't address the crux of the issue, which is the fundamental fact that you cannot exploit corpses. This is the issue, it is the core of the illogic being highlighted. Why is this something I need to point out more than once? How many people were exterminated do you think? There are many figures to source on this, but let's just go with a nice and tidy "lot's". How productive do you think those millions were after being murdered? I'd wager not very. It's a very simple scenario, and just pointing out that SOME of that resource was put to use doesn't even approach a satisfactory response to the observation that the majority was purposefully wasted, during wartime no less, and even in the face of abject military failure. To focus on irrelevant details like "yes, but he did use SOME of the undesirables" is missing the point entirely, and strikes me as a red herring. Hitler was losing, he had a virtually limitless supply of slave labour, and he killed off the majority because ultimately he saw them as vermin.

Strategically, it was an indisputably ILLOGICAL waste of resources IF one's goal is exclusively martial victory. I don't agree with Petersons claim that Hitler's goal was therefore chaos, I think that's a skin deep interpretation he's using to bolster his lecture points, but the fundamentals are here for anyone to see. Corpses do not work, and Hitler wastefully created many when he _could_ have made workers. The fact that he did make _some_ is irrelevant.

replies.author: @ObssesedNuker
replies.text:
@Niko0902 No, it was widely used. Adam Tooze makes this point in his book, The Wages of Destruction, which is considered the currently foremost work on the Nazis economy both before and during war. He showed, for example, that Speer's supposed "armaments miracle" was not driven by some magical rationalization of previous inefficiency, but by robbing the necessary coal to massively ramp up steel production from other sectors of the German economy... a process which included drafting millions of foreign workers to slave (and die) in the coal mines. A key factor in the German war effort which was utterly evil policies towards the conquered people that were very much rooted in Nazi racism. Slave labor allowed the Nazis to go well beyond what they would otherwise have been capable of through the ruthless expenditure of human life. This conclusion is unsettling to us, since we like to have what is evil also be what is ineffective, but the unfortunate fact is that foreign slave labor allowed significant increases in Nazi productivity at a time what the Germans simply had no other viable labor source. Their women were out farming, and their men were off fighting. Although foreign labor was never as efficient as German workers, the Nazis literally worked them to death for nothing.


Similarly, the death camps served a disturbingly practical purpose. The Reich faced very real food crisis after 1942, which could have crippled it had it not settled on the solution of killing large numbers of conquered peoples. The extermination of the Polish Jewry for example was not just an ideological insanity - it also had the practical effect of freeing up large amounts of food for the German war machine, which would have otherwise been faced with famine. Had Germany ACTUALLY tried to feed all its conquered citizens, it would have collapsed years earlier.


Similarly, the butchery of Slavic people was also not some unfortunate by-product but a necessity in order to make the invasion logistically feasible. The Germans simply didn't have the transport to transport the necessary foodstuffs to their troops while also maintaining the shipments of ammo and fuel necessary to fight the Soviet Union, so the Nazis resorted to the obvious solution: have the soldiers descend upon the civilian population like a horde of locusts to strip all food from the Slavic locals, dooming them to starvation. Since this would naturally inspire a lot of resistance, the application of terror in the form of mass slaughter then became a necessity as part of this requisition of food resources.

The brutality of the Nazi policies often hides the threadbare shoestring Germany waged WWII on. Germany was in terrible economic shape at the start of the war, and carried it through only by exporting much of the hardships onto its victims. This doesn't render it any less evil mind you, rather I find the opposite: the fact that Nazis chose to embark upon a war fully knowing and okay with undertaking these measures is horrifying from a moral standpoint, but it does demolish the argument advanced by Peterson that the Nazis being "nicer" (or, in his case, supposedly "more pragmatic") would have been able to get more out of Germany's resources in the same situation.

replies.author: @khnopff71
replies.text:
Don't confuse rational - sane with rational - process. Even an insane person engages in a rational process, it's just that the leaps between points are themselves irrational to an outside perspective. In other words, you can come up with a process that goes: I have black friends....so I'm not a racist....but I talk about racism and black advancement alot....and disavow it whenever I can...but I also have black friends....so I'm not a racist.

That actual process is, in and of itself, rational because it describes the exact steps involved in order to reach said conclusion. That's different than being rational ie each point based upon a independent and proven point able to sustain the thought chain throughout. Again, even irrational people's thought processes go through a 'rational' process linking themselves together. Just because you don't agree with their psychological or scientific validity or end result does not mean there is no rationality involved.

replies.author: @slushiepower819
replies.text: @luckierloser What do you think rationality means? Honest question. Emotions are visceral reactions to our environment that stimulate the brain to produce an emotional response. This process is not antithetical to reason or logic. In many cases, such responses are very rational. For example, if someone beats your child in front of you, a rational response is distress, anger, or rage. The mind dives into a panic and causes your heart to race, adrenaline to spike, and brain to launch into a fight or flight instinct. There is reason and logic behind you becoming very emotional. My point is, rationality and emotionality are not mutually exclusive.

replies.author: @luckierloser
replies.text: @slushiepower819 rationality comes from the latin word ratio and means reason. It and the word emotio, feeling, were thought of as opposit in nature. Fighting for control over man's actions. I would call behavior that is explicitly not motivated by emotions, but just by weighing all available data to come to a conclusion rational. As for your example, I wouldn't call the behavior you described rational. It would be an emotional and completely justified response. And please don't get the wrong idea, I'm not saying either is better than the other. Emotions are there for exactly the kind of situation that you described, because they, for example, make us protect our offspring, a very important thing hardwired in our brains. The bodily reactions to stress you mentioned are even more biological, and have even less to do with rationality. They are literally the animal in us taking over. And again, nothing wrong with that.

replies.author: @slushiepower819
replies.text:
@luckierloser I agree with your last point. Those emotions I referenced are, in a sense,  animalistic, primal motivations. But that still doesnâ€™t prove such actions or emotions as irrational. Youâ€™re assuming any base animalistic response is irrational. They are not. In fact, many animals make decisions strictly on the determination that such actions will improve their chances of survival; Which is very rational. Some male animals will even consume their offspring because they are hungry. Some female animals will fight predators to the death to protect their offspring. Both actions can be construed as rational. Humans have evolved from animal like states and developed the power to think and comprehend complex emotions. That doesnâ€™t mean we have excluded our ability to act rationally from our ability to feel emotions.

Your first point argues that feelings and emotions are opposite in nature because of how ancient societies determined them to be. While that may be true, (I honestly donâ€™t know) I wouldnâ€™t say that is a great argument to prove that rationality and emotionality are mutually exclusive.

â€‹@jasonfenton8250 
>You didn't explain it lol.

you said:
>The whole "clean your room before you fix society" argument is such bullshit.
> It's just a way to silence people you disagree with and undermine their authority.

I said:
>if you can't even manage your own life by "getting [it] 100% in order", why should we let people like you be in charge of managing things that, if even 1% wrong, could turn life in America into hell for some people by accident?
>Jordan Peterson makes that point about cleaning your room not to shut people out of discussion, but to say that you should gain some experience in ordering stuff before you try to go out into the world and order stuff

in short:
1) the argument has a point.
the point of the argument is as follows: learn how to control the things that are within your control in your life and manage that stuff well before you try to go out into the world and control stuff that affects the lives of others. it is NOT to say "oh, you haven't even made (random improvement X) in your life, so you're not worth listening to." if someone ever uses that argument like that against you, you have my permission to laugh in their fucking face

2) it is provably not "just a way to silence people you disagree with."
the point of the argument is for the listener to gain skill in controlling what they can control, not to tell them they lack authority to talk about something because they "haven't cleaned their room." that's not even how authority works. it is provably not that because Peterson himself never used it that way. the point was always about having control

@kingvince7328 If you harass someone, it's harassment. How is that wrong?
Here's a definition of harassment "To irritate or torment persistently." Also "to subject (another) to hostile or prejudicial remarks or actions; pressure or intimidate."
This type of law often deals with intent and emotional effect. If this misgendering is done in a manner that harasses, it's harassment. If you want to argue against the illegality of harassment, that's different.

If you misgender someone repeatedly by accident, then it's not harassment. Notice they say "might amount," it's situation dependent.

@3rd Degree Burns  @3rd Degree Burns I believe you misunderstood me, the Nazis as good populists were cleaver enough to let the healthcare system in place because it was popular and accepted in Germany.
It would have make no sense at all to dismantle it apart of losing support in a wide range of the population. Even the idea to privatize it would have made no sense in the mindset of the 30s as they were in power and so as it was a public program, they were de facto providing it.
It was the prime idea of Bismarck when he created it in the 19th century, he did it to take voters away from the Socialists and so reduce their influence nevertheless Bismarck cared for his class (aristocrat land owners) and its survival, not the lower class.
We are talking about Ideologies but also political parties and taking in account political gain by just letting in place a popular program didn't bother that much a populist party and this whatever they truly believed in that program or not.
Actually that's similar with the infrastructure (autobahn) program, Nazi propaganda boasted it helped to put back people at work, forgetting the 150.000 people at maximum who worked in a program which started in 1933 were not fully paid until 1938, the conditions of work were awful, the economy was recovering even without this autobahn program and full employment was reached thank to armament and heavy industries.
So I don't where you see I am trying to paint you as a Nazi apologist or that the Nazis were a bunch of nonsensical people.
Finally in a broader sense, this discussion revolves around the idea about what a state should do or not. In the 30s the idea of a a state providing services was popular in the majority of the western world. Whatever you or me agree with the role of a state is not the point, today after years of quasi propaganda, neoliberal, libertarian, etc. the trend can be reduced to a mantra, the smaller the state the better.

replies.author: @HeadsFullOfEyeballs
replies.text:
@3rd Degree Burns I think part of the confusion here stems from the fact that US Republicans like to pretend they're opposed to "big government". 
They aren't _actually_ opposed to it, of course -- they love bailouts and subsidies and military coups on behalf of corporations, and massively increase the national debt whenever they're in power. But they can use the "small government" thing to justify cuts to education, welfare, consumer and environmental protections and so on.
  
But "small government" isn't historically a right-wing or a conservative position. So being in favour of the government doing stuff it isn't currently doing doesn't make an ideology not-right-wing, nevermind left-wing. There are right-wing ideologies that favour strong or weak state power, and leftist ideologies that favour strong or weak state power. It's an independent axis.
 
And anyway -- the Nazis were in favour of healthcare only for people who met their eugenic standards of racial purity and fitness, and in favour of death for everyone else. Nazi medicine was an arm of their eugenics programme, not public healthcare. It's an entirely different proposition from "anyone who needs healthcare should get it", which is what the left supports.

replies.author: @davidmurray3542
replies.text:
Defining ideologies by their policies is what enables these ludicrous equivalencies. It's much more constructive to look at how the ideology would seek to distribute power.

Socialism seeks to distribute power equally among members of a society, so they are typically opposed to war and discrimination and in favour of welfare, public healthcare and reducing the power of the police.

Fascism seeks to concentrate power under those deemed "pure" and remove it from the "impure" - that can express itself in military conquest and genocide, but it might also be expressed through welfare that excludes the "impure", public healthcare that provides treatment but also sterilises the "impure", reducing policing while blaming crime on the "impure" to encourage vigilantism against them, etc.

replies.author: @McDeus
replies.text:
Hans is mostly just reciting typical boilerplate neo-Nazi bullshit propaganda. Next he'll probably be on about how the Nazis never actually murdered a single person, and it was really the Allies' fault that people imprisoned in mass-execution camps starved to death. Then probably something about Jews putting fluoride in vaccines to turn frogs gay. I wouldn't pay too much attention to people like this. They're mostly just easy marks for a political movement whose leaders are habitually lying charlatans, because they're too uninformed to spot obvious lies and fictions. 

As far as other points here, the video is not saying that Peterson is an anti-semite or a Nazi apologist. 

He's just saying Peterson doesn't understand what the Nazis' true motivation was. 

Peterson is trying to make some weird religious argument about Original Sin or whatever, even though it's plainly evident to anyone who has ever actually studied the history that the Nazis did what they did simply because it was what their ideology told them to do. 

I.e. if you're the kind of person dumb enough to believe that "race-mixing" is some horrible thing capable of destroying entire civilizations, genocide is just the logical outcome of believing that. 

The Nazis murdered people just for being members of "inferior races" because the Nazis were a bunch of racists. It's really not very complicated, and it's not some kind of mystery either, because the Nazis said that this was exactly what they were doing and why they were doing it, in explicit statements to the public, and books and newspapers they published, over and over and over again. 

The Holocaust is simply what happens when a bunch of racists are able to gain control over the institutions of government in a large modern industrial nation-state with a powerful military. 

Peterson is trying to psycho-analyze them using old, outdated Freudian theories combined with his own religious beliefs, as though there was some big mystery about why they did all this, but he's severely missing the point because there was never any mystery about it at all. 

He's guilty of ignoring the obvious simple facts of the matter because he's more interested in pushing some convoluted esoteric personal theory about it, even though his theory makes far less sense than what the simple facts clearly show to be the answer to the question he's asking. 

So, no, Jordan Peterson is not a Nazi, nor do you have to be a Nazi to be a fan of his lectures. 


You just probably shouldn't be giving any credence to anything he says about history, though, because he seems to have a habit of pontificating about it without even having a basic understanding of what he's talking about. 

(For instance, there's another video on Youtube by someone else called "Jordan Peterson Doesn't Understand Post-Modernism" that I think explains another case of Peterson's grievous historical ignorance pretty clearly.)

replies.author: @BigHenFor
replies.text:
Shara Manasgael Then do your own homework. Show how his argument is wrong. Or, do you have skin in the game? Peterson is a performing seal who likes being centre stage and being paid for his performance. He loves it so much that he will comment on stuff he really hasn't got a full grip on, and his favourite psychoanalyst, Jung is one of them. I went and researched Jung and Nazism. Guess what I found? Jung is problematic where Nazism was concerned because of his adherence to racial psychology. He actually admired Nazism during the 1930s because their pseudo-mystical mythology behind their concept of the racial inferiority of the Jews matched his own theoretical model. He thought the Nazis could bring about a reinvigoration of the spirit of the Aryan people in general, and in Germany in particular by repudiating the 'Jewish' psychology of Freud. He characterised Jewish psychology as being problematic because it focussed on the psyche being instrumental to individual agency. Meta influences were less important. Jung took the opposition position.
 He saw individual psychic behaviours were determined by race. He then lionised the Aryan psychology of being strong, noble and proud. Even though he repudiated Hitler at the end of the decade by calling him psychotic, he never gave up on the idea that race was determinative. He criticised Jews for their "unchristianess", and thought their individuality and lack of national identity at that time, made them pathological as a race. He claimed to be bemused that speaking of a "Jewish" psychology would be considered unacceptable. In these terms, appeased Hitler and was an anti-Semite. Peterson talking about Nazism and not mentioning Jung's role in legitimising Nazism is interesting. He didn't mention it, because it would have perhaps undermined his thesis. But I think his thesis about Nazism is bit obvious and doesn't explain why it gained traction. If his goal was to explain why Nazism was evil from a psychoanalytic view, he would only get a C- from me. Moreover, his "order and balance" thesis is putting the cart before the horse politically. Order and balance comes after the decision how resources in a community are to be divided. Yes, a strong man offering order and safety can influence that decision, but he doesn't explain clearly how the masses come to accept the decision and it's consequences. You may agree or you may not, but I wouldn't rely on one perspective to do my thinking for me.

replies.author: @hans-joachimbierwirth4727
replies.text:
Humans don't form hierarchies based on biological determination. Peterson is an idiot who doesn't know shit about psychology and society. And he clearly said, *all* organisms in which serotonine exists  were biologically determined to form simple hierarchies based on violence. He claimed that to be inherited from lobsters and said, that lobsters were our ancestors. I don't think there was ever an idiot in academia as stupid as Jordan Peterson. Here is the transcript (comments inserted by me):

a) "The reason that i write about lobsters is there's this idea that hierarchical structures are a sociological construct"
That's not an idea but a fact. The latter is the definition of the former. 

b) "of the western patriarchy"
What has the west to do with this? Nothing. Noone ever said that patriarchalic structures were invented by the west.

c) "and that is so untrue,"
His own strawman is untrue. The rest is a fact.

d) "that it's almost unbelievable."
Cry me a river!

e) "And i use the lobster as an example"
Lobsters (being territorial) aren't even examples of typical decapoda, which is the family they belong to. They aren't examples of anything in the vertebrate branch.

f) "we devulged from lobsters in evolutionary history about 350 million years ago. Common ancestor."
We didn't. In that context "devulged" isn't even a term. Lobsters aren't our ancestors. Lobsters didn't exist 350 million years ago. Lobsters ancestors 350 million years ago weren't our ancestors, and 350 million years ago there were no common ancestors of humans and lobsters.

g) "And lobsters exist in hierarchies."
They don't. Lobsters are solitaires who don't engage in cooperative tasks. They have neither parental investment nor bite impediments. The term "hierarchies" in scientific papers about lobsters refers to size(=age) related probabilities of observed behavioral choices in conflict.

h) "They have a nervous system attuned to the hierarchy."
Bullshit. Due to their bad eyesight lobsters can't even identify specimen of their own species correctly. They identify risk, not status.

i) "And that nervous system runs on serotonin just like our nervous systems do."
Bullshit. Serotonin is one of many components and it doesn't work in lobsters like it does in our nervous system. Serotonin controls status defined as state of mind, not status defined as social standing.  

j) "And the nervous system of the lobster and the nervous system of the human being is so similar"
Ridiculous bullshit. Neither is the biochemical setup similar, nor are the neuronal structures similar. 

k) "that anti-depressants work on lobsters."
Bullshit. Working means manipulating the amount of serotonin present. That doesn't mean this had the same effect on lobster behavior, and even if it did, that doesn't constitute similarities between lobster colonies and human societies which there aren't any.

l) "And it's part of my attempt to demonstrate that the idea of hierarchy has absolutely nothing to do with socio-cultural construction"
Lol... Jordan Peterson completely retarded? To this point none of his claims is true, and none is in any way related to human societies.

m) "which it doesn't."
Nothing to do which it doesn't? That happens when acting and posture occupies a brain so completely that there isn't enough oxygene left for the language sector and/or the logic sector. 
 
n) "I'm saying that it's inevitable that there will be continuity in the way that animals and human beings organise their structures."
Wuhahaha... Read that multiple times! Do it! Read that retarded shit! Since when organize all animals the same way, since when do they organize like we do, and since when are all human cultures the same? Is that idiot totally retarded to deny the differences in human societies over time and/or over distance?

o) "It's absolutely inevitable."
What?

p) "And there is one third of a billion years of evolutionary history behind that."
Behind what? Lobsters evolved at least half a billion years from the last common ancestor which was sort of a roundworm. That means: THEY CHANGED A LOT! That doesn't mean, they stayed the same, and his stupid "third of a billion years" is just an arbitrary number and not even related with any fact at all. You know what: We evolved over half a billion years from that same ancestor too. Makes a difference of a billion years between us and lobsters. Jordan Peterson and his uneducated fanbase are the only idiots on this planet who didn't get it.

q) "That's so long that a third of a billion years ago, there weren't even trees."

replies.author: @hans-joachimbierwirth4727
replies.text:
> "What makes it a "fact" what all hierarchies are sociological constructions?"
The semiotics of both terms make it a fact. Sociological means processed by means of mass communications and construction means artificially ordered by one or more subjects.

> "Where are you getting this information?"
Living with some hundred decapoda for years. And ofc. studying them. That includes to get familiar with scientific papers about them. 

> Also, none of the absent characteristics you listed in lobsters (if this even is true) would indicate that they don't live in hierarchies.
Lol. It doesn't seem you have the slightest clue waht you are talking about. A hierarchy is in all cases a type of social order organized by behavioral patterns specific to a species and in effect maintaining its survival by at least maintaining one factor infolved,  i. e. collective hunting or at least food distribution, care for youngsters or collective defense. None of that exists in lobster colonies. Lobsters confronted with swimming objects, predatory or non predatory fish or other lobsters behave the same. Vectors of movement, object size and distance determine their behavior. There are chemical modifiers though but such do not exist for primates. 

> "There have been multiple studies confirming that injecting lobsters with serotonin aids their ascent in a dominance hierarchy."
You're regurgitating Peterson's wrong claims. There are no lobster hierarchies beyond the paperwork of the observers who counted confrontations and retreats in lobster tanks. Laymen  like you and Peterson don't understand scientific terminology. If you measure the height of some mountains and sort them by height in a table on paper that doesn't make them live in social hierarchies!

> " it's important to note that serotonin correlates with the social standing of lobsters"
It doesn't. There is no social standing. There is no known sort of group behavior. Lobsters don't organize in groups. You don't even understand what Serotonine does. It reflects the ratio of drive and resistance dynamically, and that means: it isn't linked to social aspects at all. Serotonine reflects when you try to start your car's engine or when a child pushes against a desk with its head. That doesn't make the desk and the car dominant or subdominant social entities. Peterson is an idiot of epic proportions who doesn't even known the most simple of facts about Serotonine.

> "Humans and lobsters do have common ancestors."

That's not the point. Peterson claimed that we and them  diverged 350 million years ago, which isn't the case. 350 million years ago our ancestors already were fully developed vertebrates with four limbs and the same basically blueprint we share with all vertebrates, while crustaceans don't share anything with vertebrates. Their ancestors didn't even have the same traits lobsters and other decapoda share today. None of their attributes is present in vertebrates. The last common ancestor was a roundworm 550 million years ago who had nothing in common with us or with lobsters. We did not diverge from that branch lobsters represent today. 

> "'I've never heard of lobsters having bad eyesight."
Lobsters (like all crustaceans and insects) have compound eyes, and due to their principle construction all compound eyes have poor image resolution and no focal control. The visual cortex of a lobster is basically a simple integrator capable of determining sizes and distance of objects aswell as their movements. Morphological analyze not included. Some decapoda have quite sensitive eyes but that doesn't compensate their low resolution or their missing brain complexity.

> "They may have been brutal, genocidal dictators, but that doesn't mean they didn't know how to regulate their emotions."
It is what we know about their lack of self control from their relatives, their buddies, their medical personal and others. Their behavior in certain historical situations is extremely telling. Hitler was a nervous wreck and Stalin was a paranoid pussy mostly hiding in his Dacia and praying for help from above. When the Wehrnacht invaded he went nearly catatonic for a week.

replies.text:
Seamus Diamond: Ah ok, thank you for the correction, I might have misunderstood/misrepresented him there. And while I agree that a objective truth in political discussions might be hard to find, if at all, politics don't function through what we perceive as objective truth and they never have. Politics were, are and always will be about finding a consensus. And my point here under your representation of Petersons thought would be, that he is refusing to take part in the process of finding a consensus, because of his personal ideological disposition. No matter what you think about Marx, he was right when he said, that everything is politics, because every person does have a political opinion, that you can categorize.
If Peterson now really thinks, that a dialogue is only then a true dialogue, when both parties enter it, with the assumption, that neither of them might hold the truth, then he is just a bad discussion partner when it comes down to politics. And not only that, he is unintentionally doing exactly what he doesn't want to happen: he is entering a political debate with a certain state of mind, that prevents him from being critical towards his own political opinions ("I just simply refuse to do it"). And ultimately what this leads to is him shutting down to anything that would go beyond the status quo, simply because he fails to understand one fundamental thing about political debate: and that is that there is no objective truth as in Newtons laws for example, but rather that it's a consensual narrative that the majority of the society (at least in democratic states) agrees with.
The challenging thin about this is of course not to be on the side that completely shuts down mentally and goes on about how much better the things were 20 years ago or so, but about being able to reflect upon yourself, to consider your line of thought being fundamentally wrong or at least asking yourself the question: "Why does it bother so many people? Why are they thinking in the way they're thinking?". And for me it seems that Peterson is just not able to do that or at least not able to do that very well, which just leads to silly argumentations and twisting around things and straw-manning. This is essentially what he says in the last bit, and if I think about it, you interpretation of his line of thought, makes perfect sense: He cannot handle the idea, that there is some academic evidence, in a lot of our understanding of how our societies work, that might cause a change in the status-quo and he feels like there is a political agenda printed on to that. But you know, this is nothing unusual and it has never been, John Stuart Mill was arguing about equal right for everyone in the early 19th century, that's what shapes our cultures, societies and traditions, it's nothing we're born in and can't get away from or that or that has been there for ages without a change. And yes, I mean, if you argue, that every person should have the same rights, in times of western slavery, then you're challenging politics, in the same sense various academic fields have found out, that yes, our societies are patriarchal and it has this and that effect on a individual, then yes, of course you're triggering a political debate, and if Peterson is not able to handle that, then again, it's his own inability that's holding him back and it doesn't make a good excuse, why he should not engage in a dialogue, with people, he disagrees with.

Well, I can't really tell much about the leftists in the US, since I live in Germany, but I would certainly agree, that not a very small percentage of the left is very self-centered and kinda unwilling to deal with the reality of the average Joe and, yes a lot is definitely about identity.

Alex Ziegler

1. "IDK where you're getting the idea that he has an inability to discuss any matters or has refused to do so."

From what he says.

2. "The difference between him and those of the philosophies that he disagrees with is that he draws a line in engaging with those who will not ground themselves in science in an academic fashion "

I would accept that, but they do have a ground in academics indeed.

3. "where as those who do not speak to him or traditionalists do so because they will not accept their social beliefs."

Who doesn't want to speak to him? It's rather, that he doesn't want to speak to certain people. Please elaborate what do you mean by social beliefs?

4. "I'm curious as to what you mean by "Thuderfoot Syndrome""

Simply put, disagreeing, that anything that falls under the term social sciences are indeed academic disciplines, that need to be taken seriously.

5. "Those axioms are harder to substantiate to natural science, so when they contend with his and those with scientific or skeptical values, there is a conflict that cannot be sorted out on those terms."

But here is the thing: they don't contradict each other or are in conflict with each other, because they talk about different things. I have an example for this, from a debate I once had with an alt-righter on the subject of the equality of women and men. His point was: he brought up a study that talks about men and women being unequal in terms of physiology. This is mostly chemistry and Biology stuff, right. And that's completely true. That's why you have male soccer teams and female soccer teams for example. Now however this person, concluded, that because males and females aren't equal in terms of physiology, they are of course not equal in any sense at all, which is again wrong, because physiology doesn't mean that women can't drive a car, or vote or go to a university or do whatever else they want to do really. They are not inept to any of the things that men can do, just because they have to exercise in a different way then men, for example and even this is situational. And all of this, because this person didn't understand, that there are multiple definitions of equality, physiological equality is not the same as legal equality for example. And that's what I mean, natural sciences and social sciences don't conflict each other at all. No philosopher will ever debate that gravity does not exist and no historian will ever claim that H2O is something else then water. They just simply ask different questions. And if you as a natural scientist are unable to understand this, then you have a severe case of Thunderfoot syndrome.

replies.author: @shanearmstrong9861
replies.text:
You get fined for civil cases.

What happens if you don't pay the fine?

Follow the train of thought to its conclusion, genius.

Walking around nude isn't inherently speech, and doing so as a demonstration is protected by the first amendment in the United States. Why do you think the bra-burners in the 1970s were allowed to walk around topless in NYC as part of a demonstration? To be nude just for the sake of being nude in the US is cited as indecent exposure, and is largely a matter of state or municipal statute, not federal law. Bill C-16 has been ratified as a FEDERAL LAW IN CANADA. It is not illegal to be nude in a nudist community. It IS illegal to misgender someone no matter what part of Canada you live in.

The only time free speech is unlawful is in the event that it involves harassment of an individual by threatening their safety, or by threatening violence/calling for violence to a person or group of people. 

These are the only exceptions, and the only reasonable exceptions, as they directly involve the physical harm of a person without justification. Misgendering someone doesn't cause them physical harm.  Your argument about public indecency laws has nothing to do with free speech and is an utter farce of a non-sequitur, especially considering that it is completely legal to be nude as a demonstration, as I've proven. 

You do not have the moral authority to force me to be nice to someone or to force me to address them as they wish to be addressed. No one does, and I will stand against this law for precisely that reason, for as long as it remains a law. 

Just because the government CAN compel people doesn't mean it ought to. There must be a justification for doing so that NECESSITATES their involvement, otherwise their intervention is inherently unjust. Advocating that the government step in and arbitrate everything right down to the minuta of human interaction is how we arrive in a one-party police state where there are no freedoms beyond what the people in power dictate, and I refuse to allow that society to come into fruition. I will not have my rights trampled upon, and I will actively resist anyone who attempts to do so.

replies.author: @shanearmstrong9861
replies.text:
Patently and factually incorrect. Bill C-16 extends a provision to the Federal Government to penalize anyone who engages in "Hate Propaganda" based on sexual identity or gender expression.

What does the Canadian government define as Hate Propaganda?

2.2.1 Hate Propaganda
Criminal offences related to hate promotion are set out in sections 318 to 320.1 of the Criminal Code. Section 318 makes it an offence for anyone to advocate or promote genocide, which is defined as acts committed with an intent to destroy in whole or in part an identifiable group by either killing its members or inflicting on them such conditions as to deliberately bring about their physical destruction. Those found guilty may be punished by up to five yearsâ€™ imprisonment.

Section 319(1) makes it a criminal offence to incite hatred against any identifiable group where this is likely to result in a breach of the peace. Section 319(2) makes it an offence to communicate, except in private conversation, statements that wilfully promote hatred against an identifiable group, whether by telephone, broadcasting or other audible or visible means.

Now, Section 318 I take no issue with.

Section 319 subsection 1, however, is of note. 

It is a criminal offence to incite hatred against any identifiable group where this is likely to result in a breach of the peace.

What does this mean? 

It is up to a court of law if your speech is an incitement of hatred against a group that would result in a breach of the peace.

What constitutes a breach of the peace?

According to section 175.

section 175. (1) Every one who 
(a) not being in a dwelling-house, causes a disturbance in or near a public place, 
(i) by fighting, screaming, shouting, swearing, singing or using insulting or obscene language, 
(ii) by being drunk, or 
(iii) by impeding or molesting other persons, 
(b) openly exposes or exhibits an indecent exhibition in a public place, 
(c) loiters in a public place and in any way obstructs persons who are in that place, or 
(d) disturbs the peace and quiet of the occupants of a dwelling-house by discharging firearms or by other disorderly conduct in a public place or who, not being an occupant of a dwelling-house comprised in a particular building or structure, disturbs the peace and quiet of the occupants of a dwelling-house comprised in the building or structure by discharging firearms or by other disorderly conduct in any part of a building or structure to which, at the time of such conduct, the occupants of two or more dwelling-houses comprised in the building or structure have access as of right or by invitation, express or implied, 
is guilty of an offence punishable on summary conviction. 

It can therefore be inferred that by saying something deemed hateful to a person of a protected gender identity, such as would lead them to potentially start an altercation, I have committed a criminal offence. That is the extent and limit that the law describes within its purview. Whether or not it is actively enforced in such a way is up to the people enforcing it, but that is the limit of the law, to the letter.

Now, arguably, the root of this issue lies with 319 (1) and not C-16 in general, but as the two are inherently linked, they both are problems for the Canadian public in general. The only way I would support C-16 would be after the repeal of 319 (1) and replacement of a more reasonable standard by which criminal offense can be judged, or else a re-branding of C-16 to exclude the vague term "Hate Propaganda", which apparently just means saying something about X protected quality of a person that might piss that person off enough to make them scream, swear sing, use insulting or obscene language.

replies.author: @shanearmstrong9861
replies.text:
Should I get you some more hay to stuff into that strawman you've built?

>" The fact that you don't realize that JP believes in what he says so much that he presumes them as rules which is equivalent to a law shows how complete oblivious you are to social pressure."

He offers them as rules or guidelines to help people better themselves and live a more stable and successful life. He is not advocating his book to be the basis for fucking laws. Where anywhere has he stated that his book should be used as a precursor for legislation, and furthermore, how do you even begin to do the mental gymnastics to assume that he intends the  contents of a self-help book to be  law?

That is patently fucking absurd. I don't even know how you begin to make that sort of leap between him launching a self-help book, and the title of it somehow being indicative of his desire to autocratically force his viewpoint upon others through the legal system. Maybe you should stop playing Armchair psychologist to an actual psychologist before you make even more of a fool of yourself.

replies.author: @shanearmstrong9861
replies.text:
Most Psychologists don't write self-help books.

How do you know what he believes? All of this is an assumption you're taking based off of one definition of the word rule and implying that because he suggests that as the title of his book, that means he is using it as a deterministic interpretation of his worldview becoming law. You could just as easily say that the reason he uses the word Rule is because a Rule requires discipline to be enforced, and all of his suggestions require great amounts of self-discipline and self-policing in order to achieve. It is not an easy thing to build new habits. It is not an easy thing to be productive and to make time to schedule among a busy day full of distractions. Doing these things however is much more likely to see you make productive use of your time and to be successful as a result. 

Moreover, nowhere does Peterson say you are compelled to follow what he says. He offers up his wisdom as a way to live a more ordered, structured life, in order to better achieve success. He draws upon a lot of wisdom from all of the people he has worked with, the great volume of reading he has done, and the  colleagues he has discussed with as well as hos own personal experience to make these "rules". He makes the suggestion you do so, because to not do so is to live a life that is chaotic and will likely involve a lot of suffering as a consequence, and as someone personally who HAS lived a life that runs largely contrary to Peterson's ideas, I can't disagree with the man.

I don't know that his rules will remedy my personal situation, but they have given me a personal jumping off point to start setting my life in order and making something of myself. Out of all of that, you are the ONLY person who I have ever met who takes a completely literal interpretation of Peterson's rules. You take it more literally than even he does, by all accounts, because you seem to be the only one claiming that to be the case.

I finding ridiculous, bordering on conspiracy theory levels of lunacy for you to be suggesting that it is his intent to force the public by law to follow his self-help book, and to compare it to Mein Kampf of all fucking things. The fundamental difference you seem to be forgetting is that Hitler advocated using chlorine gas on the Jewry, and Peterson advocates using Clorox on your bed sheets. You'll forgive me for missing the page where Peterson claims that the Dragon you need to slay is the Jew, and the Princess is Europe.

replies.author: @shanearmstrong9861
replies.text:
Of course he takes what he writes literally, he's a clinical psychologist who has spent years of his life helping people get their lives in better shape. That does not mean a set of general ideas that he has passed down in the form of a self-help book necessarily means that he intends those values to become a one-size fits all solution to absolutely everyone's life that he would see instilled as law if given the chance, which seems to be what you are implying he desires, based off of nothing more than the ill-fitting definition of a word you are slapping onto the title of said book.

You are actively engaged in implying that he is an autocrat on the scale of Hitler because he has offered up a self-help book for people to help get their lives in order in order to be more successful, and are using your own interpretation of the word rule to try to prove that's what he intends, because according to you, there can be no other interpretation of what he intends by it. Do you not fucking comprehend how ludicrous that sounds to literally everyone? Do you not actually realize that you are trying to force your own interpretation of that word as being the only possible interpretation of it as the basis of this argument you're making? Does that not come off to you as autocratic?

But since you're clearly busy sperging out over the word rule and what it means, I went ahead and got something for you, since you seem to be a little busy trying to paint JP as the next Hitler.

https://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/rule

Go ahead and read off Definitions 1a, then 1c, then 2a 1 and 2, and then 2c for me. Ask me if any of those definitions wouldn't also suit Peterson's 12 Rules For Life, and if any of them do or could fit in place of the assumption you've made, then ask yourself why NECESSARILY that your assumption that he must be implying an autocratic demand over everyone MUST be the only possible scenario. 

And when you're done that, maybe you take some time and consider why Albert Einstein, a man who had to live with a handler for the majority of his life in order to get anything done, shouldn't serve as de facto proof that messy people can be successful. But just in case you're still too busy hunting secret Nazis, I'll do you the favor of filling out this train of logic for you.

For one, Einstein occupied the top 5% of the bell curve for human intelligence, and secondly, he made his career successful BECAUSE he was so overwhelmingly intelligent, IN SPITE of his disorganized life. 95% of people don't approach being anywhere NEARLY as gifted as that man. Therefore, how can you honestly advocate a lifestyle for the majority that only a very gifted minority who CARRY THEMSELVES on those gifts are likely capable of accomplishing, and even then only with help?

And no, despite you continuing to strawman him, Peterson has never claimed anywhere that cleaning your room PREVENTS failure. He has said that being orderly and organized, and making better use of your time and space makes you MORE LIKELY to succeed. The most likely strategy to succeed can still fail, and he has never once acted or claimed otherwise. He has stated several times that he casts no aspersions on how absolutely miserable life can be for a lot of people and states clearly that his advice is no perfect panacea to live a gilded life. If anything, he has said that, at best, his rules and self-help advice will maybe be able to help you keep things together during the worst times in your life, like a funeral, and to perhaps help you to be the rock that your family can rely on when something awful happens in life, and that, if nothing else, that seems to him like an admirable and reasonable goal to aspire to.

So in closing, how about you quit putting words in his mouth that he never said, quit attributing things to him that he has never implied, stop pretending he's some secret Nazi-esque figure planning to force people to "clean your room, bucko, or else", and stop being a massive hypocrite. That you have the gall to accuse me of strawmanning you when not only are you actively doing exactly that, but you cannot even demonstrate how I have strawmanned you at all is laughable. If you can even provide one place where I've taken something you've said out of context in order to build an argument you aren't making and use that as the basis to try to refute your argument, I will eat my sock.

Go ahead, I'll wait.

replies.author: @shanearmstrong9861
replies.text:
I never said to ignore the others, YOU'RE THE ONE POSITING THAT YOUR DEFINITION MUST BE CORRECT, USING YOUR DEFINITION AS PROOF.

I'm done arguing your little tautological loop. You haven't asked Peterson for his thoughts on this matter, you'd rather sit here and imply that he is as bad as Hitler. And if it was your intention to simply use Adolf Hitler, the most hated and reviled figure in all of human history to date as a convenient example of a man who prescribes a worldview to others, absent of the connotations or connections to Nazism, then you are either incredibly naive or incredibly disingenuous. You cannot sit there and say "Well, I only meant to compare him to Hitler because Hitler also wrote a book that told people what they should do."

You're completely ignoring the contents of both books to make such a vague generalization and the only reason anyone would ASSUME you are using Hitler for an example instead of, I don't know, maybe a John Edwards, or some other quack peddling nonsensical self-help advice to prove your point, is because YOU WANT PEOPLE TO MAKE THAT ASSOCIATION. Don't sit here and play coy like you don't know what you're doing by invoking that name.

Don't sit here and try to downplay the parallels you're attempting to link to the man after the fact. Nowhere, not even once, has Peterson EVER advocated for the rights of others to be impugned upon. Mein Kampf was literally a book calling for the end of the international Jewry. The two are NOTHING alike.

If you simply want to challenge the rise of a cult of personality, then where the hell were you to critique Obama when he was the media's darling? Or do you only go after authors who don't posit progressiveness as the highest moral order to achieve towards?

"He's made it very clear that if you don't follow these rules, you'd get no where in life whatever that really means. You will also suffer negative consequences."

And you know what, I"m more wont to believe him, a man who has spent his life working with people to improve their lives as HIS JOB, then to listen to you, a nobody critiquing his worldview as a part of someone else's youtube video.

Obviously his statements are generalizations. This is not to say that there aren't people who can't live outside of the standard and make due, and maybe there are several people whom that works for just fine. Does he say anywhere that they have to stop what they're doing if it works for them and abide only by what he prescribes? Anywhere at all?

He wrote his book as a means for people who didn't get a solid explanation of life from the people around them in order to help them find a way to sort things out, to find some meaning in their lives, and to work towards goals that will hopefully make them happier with their situation than they already are, I.E. the majority of the kinds of people that clinical psychologists regularly deal with on a day to day basis. You know who doesn't tend to pick up a self-help book? People who don't need help figuring their lives out.

If someone already has everything sorted, why the hell should they care what Peterson says? It's not as though his advice is aimed at them. I can't imagine he would expect someone who is already successful to need an antidote to chaos. 

And yes, of course chaos will exist regardless of how much work you put into sorting things out. His book is labelled as an antidote, not a cure or "the solution". Life is inherently chaotic. Existence is chaos, fundamentally. We, however, as human beings have a knack and general tendency for making order OUT of chaos in order to live our lives in a more beneficial, less stressful way. 

That doesn't mean there aren't people who have different ways of looking at order, and that doesn't mean there aren't nihilists who give into the chaotic meaninglessness of everything and simply act as agents of chaos in their own lives and the lives of others. Generally speaking though, these people tend to be in the minority of people, so why is the idea of a general guide offered to help the majority so inherently offensive to you? The way you seem so desperate to tie Peterson to Hitler, you'd swear the man said something foul about your mother.

replies.text:
> point of that chapter was to show that lobsters have hierarchies
That chapter is the most telling about Peterson's bullshit. It i based on abstract mining without reading the full text, and his claims about lobsters are creationist level drivel. He claims lobsters to be around since more than 350 million  years, and to be human ancestors. The are neither, and his "dominance hierachies" of lobsters don't even exist. The terms are taken from an abstract and refer to tables of obeserved confrontations in tanks. He claims lobsters to be representative for all species which they are not. They are decapoda and within that group they are the exception for being territorial, not the rule. Decapoda don't have social orders. Lobsters don't coordinate their behavior. They don't live in packs or swarms. There is nothing in their behavioral patterns that is in any thinkable way similar or comparable with behavioral patterns of vertebrates, not to mention primates or humans. So his whole chapter about that is bullshit.

replies.author: @anticapitalism-z3b
replies.text:
"antifa members laugh at Jordans comments, all while they are literally living in a disorganized room in their parent's basement..." 

You haven't provided any evidence at this point in your comment that antifa members live in their parent's basements. 

You should know that accusing leftists of living in their parents' basements is a standard-issue dis made by rightists. Indeed, I've had it hurled at me many times even though I own a mortgage and work 50 hour work weeks. 

Every political tendency has some devotees that are unemployed and whose lives seem stalled out in various ways. I guarantee you that many such people--unemployed and adrift--hold views far closer to yours than mine. 

In any case, the evidence that you present to support your "argument" that antifa is comprised of people living in disorganized rooms in their parents' basements is totally braindead and revealing of your total lack of understanding of the political tendency that you're attempting to criticize: 

"This is based in fact that there are many more young democrats...." 

Dude, antifa are NOT Democrats. Left radicals despise the Democratic Party and rightly see it as a graveyard for social movements against the capitalist status quo. If you are a centrist as you suggest, I can guarantee you that your politics are far, far closer to those held by Democrats like Bill Clinton and Barack Obama--both of whom as president carried water for Wall Street, the Pentagon, and the national security apparatus their entire presidencies--than are those held by left radicals who participate in or support antifa. 

But even putting aside the fact that you think wrongly that antifa are Democrats, your argument still is weak. You say that: 

"there are many more young Democrats on welfare programs, without jobs, and often on housing or living in parent's basement." 

This is such a confused and confusing statement I have a hard time knowing where to begin. 

You say there are more young Democrats of the type you describe but don't specify more than *what*. More young Democrats than young Republicans? Dude, most young people don't identify with or belong to either shitty corporate political party, ut their estrangement from the Republican Party is more severe than from the Democratic Party. A very small percentage of young Americans--let's say younger than 30--belong to or identify with the Republican Party. For this reason most statements that begin with something along the lines of "There are more young Democrats than young Republicans who" will be true. Let's try that on: There are more young Democrats than young Republicans who work as teachers, computer programmers, delivery drivers, child care workers, bike messengers, lawyers...all true. 

If you want to talk about percentages of each group, you're going to have to pony up with some evidence to support your claim(s), which you have not done.

replies.author: @Graknorke
replies.text:
Even his "clean your room" tier stuff is framed as political prescription. There is a pretty explicit message in it that you should not engage with large scale change since you can't change the world and would do harm if you tried. Instead you should just focus on yourself and try and be happy with your situation. 

It's a pretty fucked worldview, that if you follow it to its conclusion would involve be telling black protestors in mid 20th century USA to sit down and be quiet and just work on themselves. And the same to suffragettes in Europe, or factory workers in the industrial Revolution striking for safe working conditions, or Republicans in France wanting to abolish the injustice of monarchy, or plebians in ancient Rome fighting against the rigid caste system, and so on and so on. 

And yet when you look at those things, they are key to the "Western" tradition of striving for equality that Peterson claims to promote. One of his stated beliefs conflicts with the other, and in the end I think it's because neither is true. In reality he's just a bog standard conservative who wants the darn lefties to stop trying to change things, but he's learned that faux self help is a better vehicle for getting that message across to a receptive audience than just saying it would be.

author: @jonathanschmidt7874
text:
I remember how I first got into contact with the Lobster. It was with his Cathy Newman interview and the Real-Time appearance. Then I watched a bit more and also read 12 rules for life. And while I scoffed at some of the more problematic aspects (I was raised in a social-democratic and socially progressive household in Germany after all), it helped me overcome some issues I had. I'm a biologist and have a healthy working knowledge of most major Stem fields and so when I then heard him talking about climate change I was like ... wow, if he is this horribly wrong on a subject I do understand - not just with his conclusions, but also displaying a clear lack of competence when interpreting basic research data - then how wrong is he, when it comes to subjects I don't know enough about and would just take him at his word. The next thing I saw of him was the video you were addressing and I was like ... holy shit, this is embarrassing. You don't need to be a university student in a history undergrad class, to see how little he actually knows and how grossly he misrepresents Nazi ideology, but just a basic German high school education which makes it even sadder. I paused the video and found yours in the recommendations and it was a cathartic experience. Thanks for doing what you do. 
I don't think, I was never in any real danger of going down the Alt-Right pipeline, but I'm nevertheless happy that I realized their bullshit before they got a real opportunity to hook me in. Your videos, as well as Shawn's and many other Breadtubers, made a difference in my life. And that's awesome!

replies.author: @andreaslundberg2978
replies.text:
@johnweatherby8718That is a bad approach, for quite a few reasons.

1. A high H index is often the result of being the manager of several peojects where others do the actual research. I do not know how many of Petersons publications have come about that way but I know some of them have because the very abstract of the articles said so.

2. When a professor and a doctor in a field make differing claims about the same study then often the one who gives the least grandiose claims and actually describes the study is more to be trusted. Not the one with most unrelated publications to their name.

3. If you can't judge claims yourself (not having access to the source, too little knowledge in the area) you can check other claims and see if they show you who seems more prone to false claims.
You can look up Bill C-16 and see that Jordan Peterson was wrong (as a whole organization of experts pointed out). You can read the story of Cain and Abel to see that Peterson is wrong about the text strongt implying that Cain's heart was not in his sacrifices. 
You can hear him claim that quitting smoking requires supernatural experiences and then talk with any person who have managed without such nonsense. 
Then of course, you can listen to his rambling about depictions of twin snakes being about DNA after which you real up on the mating behavior of snakes. 
If you still find him mote trustworthy than a psychologist actually discussing his references in some depth, because of his H value, that is a bit worrying.

author: @DemocracyArchive
text: I will say that the whole "if you can't determine what motivates someone directly, look at the outcome and then infer the motivation is terrible historically." History depends heavily on primary sources, meaning that it requires direct textual or witness-based evidence from someone who was at the event in question or had direct knowledge of that event. Secondary sources look people writing about said event, usually with the support of primary sources. These two types of source, combined together, help build our historical understanding and in the absence of the said two types of sources, we can infer and know nothing. Furthermore, to infer the motivation of a historical figure via the outcome of their actions is very weak methodology for historical understanding. For one, it requires that we assume a historical figure has more control over the outcome of a historical event. In reality, very few exercise such control and even those who do have such control lose it eventually. In most cases, historical figures are not just acting on the world, but also reacting to it and sometimes events happen that they can't predict nor control. It also creates an absurd opportunity for subjective speculation to mix with fact and call itself objective. People are subjective creatures and if they simply infer the motivation via the outcome, they will think not as the historical figure's did within their respective times, but within the confines of their own modern interpretation. Thus, history and historical accuracy is lost. Jordan Peterson may be an excellent psychologist, but he is terrible at history.

But it's an important thing to do, because we can't fix a problem we don't acknowledge. If we don't recognize the existance of hate within us, we'll never be able to face it, change it. Simply labeling such actions as evil is an effort to ignore their underlying causes and more importantly, an effort to not face them. That, in a way, is the real purpose society gives to the concept of evil; it's an escapegoat from our own demons.

Petersons basic point is valid, that people often don't do things for completely rational reasons, even when they themselves thinks so and/or publicly claim so. replies.text:
â€‹@undeadwill5912 doesn't he love to thrown around the term "cultural marxism"? Kind of hard to take an anti-semtic dog whistle out of context. It's a classic paleoconservative talking point kept vague enough to allow for deniability when needed.

Also doesn't he like to throw around the Venezuela argument as a talking point against socialism? (Never mind that Venezuela is a Social Democracy, vastly different from pure socialism) While ignoring the FACT that Venezuela was dealt significant economic blows thanks to US sanctions, US backed coups and poor policy in the face of an oil price crash?

Doesn't he also define equity as equality of outcome that the left strives for? This is not only practically impossible, but is factually false as most leftists will agree that equality of opportunity is a far more realistic goal. That is the typical consensus you reach when you have a productive discussion/debate between Communists, Liberals and even Centrists.

Didn't he also misrepresent bill C-16? I remember when the Canadian BAR association actually had to come out and debunk his talking points because he horribly misrepresented what C-16 was about. Never mind the fact that the law was already in the books five years prior in several provinces, and there were ZERO arrest regarding improper pronoun usage. The bill just applied this on a federal level and yet to this day still no arrests.

Of course I may just be taking him out of context so I may need some clarification here.

replies.author: @luki907
replies.text: â€‹@WhiskeyTangoFoxtrot_YT I still don't understand why this new wave of resentment towards Peterson insists that he misrepresented the bill. A The Ontario Human Rights Commission can commence a complaint before a Tribunal, intervene in any existing complaint before the Tribunal on behalf of any complainant, conduct its own inquiries into real or purported breaches of the Code and issue recommendations, and it develops legally binding policies. With the introduction of Bill C-16, the OHRC has the authority to require you to use the words demanded by the bill. To reiterate, OHRC policy requires that persons must use the pronouns required by the portion of transgendered individuals, making that demand effectively constitutes compelled speech. Those not wishing to use those pronouns or not able to use those pronouns due to their beliefs, faith and religion, are afforded no ability to abstain. People can be summoned to a human rights Tribunal if they use the wrong words. Wilfed Laurier University was proof of that. You can say I'm wrong, tell me my facts are irrelevant, but none of that really matters since the bill is already in place. Your speech doesn't matter in this country. Nor does mine.

replies.author: @WhiskeyTangoFoxtrot_YT
replies.text:
@luki907 Because Peterson's hand wringing after the skeptic community picked it up was poor in optics. He knew this but choose to let it run it's course with him benefiting from the media coverage, thus developing detractors.

Also in regards to C-16. Nothing in the language was written to COMPEL the use or avoidance of certain words in public. As long as there is no malicious intent behind the words then no law is broken.

If a person talks to a transwoman and accidentally calls her a male pronoun, they are not subject to jail time or fines. How ever if they call her a man over and over in a malicious manner or they advocate the death of her and her ilk or publicly incites hatred towards them. Then that clearly is intending to antagonize, and that person violates anti-hate speech laws. All the bill is designed to do is move transgender individuals into an already existing group of protected classes.

If Canadians don't like the level of free speech they have in their country then they can elect officials that are more for free speech absolutism. Until then, misconstruing C-16 does not serve a practical purpose in the free speech debate.
