@jamiehardt3061 Well, you still doing that( i.e you attribute "roles, "places" as where I belong and adjectives to me) although this time in a much milder form:) Having discussions over the internet, especially in the "youtyube" comment section admittedly could have that, let's say, side effect. But still, please don't do that.
    While I don't know everything, about the Holocaust and let's say the nazi's deeds(who could actually, or willing to do that even if it is VERY important), you didn't say ANYTHING new to me. While I'm not a scholar on history, I'm very passionate about it. But you still assume ( quite wrongly I could say) that I'm in the definitive need of more "reading" ( well, there is certainly no such thing as enough, ONLY if one decides that for himself). What you have to understand about me is that my mind works in " big jumps" I'm not excelling in linear thinking, so to speak.I can accurately understand wide and deep concepts , along  with their implications in a second.
    
   
 You mentioned scary things, but the really scary thing is the emergence of today's "safe spaces".Yes, it is very close to the aforementioned ideology.I'm sure that I don't have to translate for you their quest for what " spaces"? Yes you are correct, it IS the same thing. We can argue about the apparently wildly different motivations and 'justifications" for the "need" of them, but in its effect only muddies the water and actually preclude the correct conclusions. 
    On top of that, NONE in the academia actually explained the poor idiots, what they were doing.(even if they could be regarded as a byproduct of the capitalist system). I know that Marx and implicitly marxism advocates exactly that( the necessity of the presence of disgruntled, uneducated masses AND the necessity of sitting tight and waiting for that) , but again it denotes the dangerous,profoundly  inhumane nature of this ideology. Not to mention the fact that marxism along  with its other derivatives behaving, EXACTLY in the way you described that other ideology.
   But I'm stoked about the fact that you as a scholar you are protesting Peterson and not actually understanding what he is doing and more importantly why. So if there is a chance to stop the next Hitler or Stalin, we should NOT do that? Any way its possible?
Think again. It is actually a human "thing" not liking someone, but that's a very different thing.
   I"m NOT advocating fascist measures, again I advocate the need for human centric education, because the current system clearly failed. Marx works still should be taught about, but with the MANDATORY cautioning and explanation about its pitfalls and all the wrongness

   Again discussing various concepts philosophies and teachings by their effect on humanity is a different kind of discussion.
But, again not taking into account the spiritual nature of religions vs the more practical part of actual ideologies, makes it akin to pseudoscience.That's one of the reasons why marxism (this time with his broader term) IS incredibly dangerous.See my first comment on that. Science should be about the truth, NOT only the facts, because it will not expose us the whole picture, it will be a partial and very incomplete. Human "truths" and human narratives are incredibly important, because again we can relate to those at human level, MUCH easier.
   This is especially true discussing history, because history is actually HUMAN history and no one can separate from it like a minor inconvenience Again in history context is king, so understanding motivation is key,  in order to correctly asses action and understanding action is key,  in order to correctly asses motivation. That two way interaction will give us the whole picture.
Discussing only one aspect will give us only one aspect, ergo an one sided and ultimately incorrect picture.
    Apropo two way interaction, that is happening in every society. Society (in various ways) acts upon the individual
and the individual acts upon society. By definition the individual IS the smallest component ( let's say atom) of any society and ANY 'science" that does not takes that into account, it is akin to a complete and utter joke, much in the same way that one should regard alchemy vs chemistry.Today's "social sciences" are still in the dark ages.

 And now we are getting closer to the truth, namely to the importance of personal truth's, be it beliefs or convictions.The axiomatic nature of the personal (individual) truths has and had a profound effect upon our societies be it  negative or positive.
  On the negative side one has to mention (evidently) Hitler, on the positive Gandhi or Martin Luther King to name just a few.
Ignoring the effects that those personal beliefs are played upon our history is both incredibly stupid and actually dangerous.
That's why narratives ARE incredibly important, because we can relate to them much "easier"

More to come.

    Apropo you completely dismissed my "reductions" even if they DID accurately depicted the 'protective nature" of fascism and the deterministic, systematic and totalitarian nature of nazism. So you see you can protest the simplified nature of them, but NOT the accuracy historical or otherwise. Because " scholarly correct" argumentation ( i.e what you called "dogma" and how that dogma was 'created") can't really replace personal ,individual (critical and/or judgemental) thinking.it IS important. but again it will give you an one sided view and actually could hamper personal development.( i.e thinking with your own head)
    T

@THEMOSTGODLESS8713GGR
replies.text:
@PabloCardonaMusic 
Not quiet solutions ----- Cleaning your room doesn't translate to MUCH of anything, unless you tell me that successful, ordered (as against chaos, he says) people make sure they clean their rooms every morning, and the same applies to all other 11 "rules" Some of them are palpably pathetic as orientation for young boys, those "rules" remind me a lot of LAZY teachers (most of them) that give busy-work to students just to keep them busy and stopping them from enjoying their lives, and actually exploring. Â 

Look, we "older" people know teenagers are a pain in the ass, so MOST of us give teens and young adults a lot of slack and leeway, let them do their stupid shit and find themselves like we all did, but Peterson has thisÂ 
anti-chaos or some sort of mental super-structure he wants to impose on everyone as a way to find CONTENTMENT and his way is to basically keep things as they are, Want happiness? it doesn't exist, he says, the best you can do is get married and adopt, or "shoulder" as much responsibility as you can handle, and his recent stint in a rehab place gives you an indication of where taking as much responsibility as you can will lead you, we all almost automatically take as much as we can and DO as much as we are able to. 
You want a very ordered world?? well friend, it just doesn't exist, and never has existed, we all live in FLUX our entire lives, embrace change and chaos and learn to deal with those and dominate them because THAT is the one CONSTANT in life, change! 

As Orwell said in his book Animal Farm, We are all equal, but some are more equal than others, and even Peterson argues FOR that when the topic is hierarchies and differences between theTWO sexes, etc etc, so "social issues" will always be there for us to deal with, every time you deal with the world, REALITY, you must take those "issues" into account. 

Now, do I wish it to be different?? I guess not, and it is a useless question to begin with, because it cannot be different, The TOTALLY equal society where there is no suffering and no disparity among people seem to me like the idea people have of heaven, and that place is boring as shit and the things people say to do there are horribly narcissistic and tedious.Â 

So I have come to make peace with the fact that life is struggle with times (not "moments", as Peterson says) of enjoyment and peace. But even people who could live doing absolutely nothing keep doing shit to keep busy or "better" the world, and some to damage the world... why in the world would you or anyone else with it to be any different, better to face the HORRIBLE facts, because they are horrible, and hope to better the world, KNOWING it can never be achieved. But cleaning your room or not bothering a cat or listening to everyone as if they have something to teach you is not the way, hell, even Peterson doesn't listen to EVERYONE.

What you said about thinking about short medium and long consequences is spot on, but DIDN'T WE ALL ALREADY KNOW THAT??  But how is anyone gonna learn to do that properly by cleaning your room!!!
You can make a word salad and connect the two like Peterson does, but that is just that; it is woo. "He does that with his bible stories, his Pinocchio analogies about going to the underworld by going into the belly of the whale and saving your father, or becoming a real man because you are not one like Pinocchio, etc etc... he does that a lot. 
His best arguments are in the areas he actually knows about and had data to back it up, Hierarchies, differences between men and woman.... but SOME of his conclusions are horribly misguided.

Good luck.

replies.author: @THEMOSTGODLESS8713GGR
replies.text:
@PabloCardonaMusic 
One more thing about those solutions you mentioned, that "seem to work"

In exercise there is a known fact: if you have beeb sitting on your ass doing basically NOTHING physical for years, and suddenly take up ANY activity, well, it WORKS, it does improve your health and physical well being... but then if you are sitting on your ass for years , then ANYTHING you do that gets you off your ass will work wonders. The point is (as in the "clean your room" analogy) how far can you go, and once you get adapted to that activity you picked up, what happens once your body get ADAPTED to it??  So you get the amateur or newbie benefits of finally getting off your ass, and that lasts for a few weeks or months depending on the sport, and then what??  Do you see? Cleaning your room is similar, if it is a complete mess it will help some, but unless you continue FREVER then the benefits don't last, same if you have baad relations with family or friends, ANYTHING you do to try to fix them will help... butte nirvana people think will follow is just not true.
What Peterson does is like those ads that want you to invest with them, they show the EXCEPTIONAL people who got EXCEPTIONAL results, then they tell you that YOU TOO can get those and that is easy, but of course they cannot guarantee it, because those results will vary and most people end up BROKE.

replies.text: There are multiple lenses to infer an understanding of something, and just because it's one of them doesn't mean it's the highest priority. Sometimes you've got better tools and better data. Sometimes you don't.

I also want to challenge you with this: Have you actually read up on Karl Jung which Jordan Peterson adores? IMHO it puts Peterson in perspective. Karl Jung peddles Depak Chopra style New Age mumbo jumbo. I say mumbo jumbo, because having a father who is into this I have seen how crazy this stuff is. My father was also a Karl Jung fan.


Karl Jung, and thus by extension Jordan Peterson is VERY far away  from mainstream science in the understanding of psychology and the human mind. Remember he hails from a time when psychologists had no way of actually introspecting and analyzing the human brain. Today we have CAT scans, MRI and a host of other methods to connect human behavior to physical processes in the brain we can observe.


Jordan Peterson is really peddling pseudo science. But as a well read scholar, your average debater knows to little about this stuff to confront him, and thus he often scores points in debates.

replies.author: @owabowa
replies.text:
@tilltronje1623 Hey there, I got some question. 

First of all, is it taboo or stigmatized to even talk about the nazis in Germany?

Second of all, how is it to hear (mostly americans in my experience) people say that the nazis were "actually socialists"? 

Third of all, is there any books or documenteries about WW2 that you would recommend?

replies.author: @tilltronje1623
replies.text:
@owabowa 1. No, it is not. The only requirement is to be respectful. Nazis are permanently present in history documentaries you can watch every night on TV, we have multiple days of rememberance for Nazi atrocities and related events, monuments to the victims are scattered all across the country (and NONE to the perpetrators unlike in the US) and the Nazis are present in close to every year in school. And not just history, but also in German class, English, religion, arts, music and sociology. Many German students visit concentration camps. I myself have stood in the gas chambers of Dachau. It is the opposite of taboo. Making it taboo would only increase the risk of it happening again.  Nazi jokes aren't very popular though, because it implies a lack of respect for their victims. You can make them but they have to be very good (and I expect foreigners really shouldn't joke). Some German exchange students tell of being greeted by Americans with Hitler salutes "as a joke". A punch to the face can very well happen in those cases so that should give you some idea. In short: feel free to talk about the Nazis with Germans but be respectful. Don't ask "was your dad a Nazi?" (many Germans will tell you about that themselves)

2. At first it is laughable to hear. Every fithgrader here knows what the Nazis and their politics were. But as you go deeper into US politics it becomes scary as you realise that this is not just some ignorant idiocy but a widespread view many Americans have about the Nazis. The main problem is that Americans who say this are falling for and spreading Nazi propaganda as the term socialist was purposefully included by the Nazis to manipulate people into their cause. 

3. Many of those are in German so I am not familiar with international ones. As for books there are 2 I really like that can shed light on how the German army operated and thought about Nazism and the war and on how the Nazis managed to make nearly  all of Germany go along with their atrocities. Those are "Soldaten. On fighting, killing and dying" by Harald Welzer and SÃ¶nke Neitzel and "TÃ¤ter. How ordinary men become mass murderers" by Harald Welzer. I am not sure about English versions though. 
Other than that I recommend some movies that shed light on the German side and the Nazis and aren't the typical American films which want to make war look exciting. You might get depression from these though. 
"Das Boot" (the boat) is probably the best war film ever made
"Der Untergang" (Downfall) details the collapse of the Nazi regime and the last days of Hitler
"Stalingrad" shows the brutal war on the eastern front
"Sophie Scholl. The final days" tells the story of a German resistance group who gave their lives to try and end Nazism
Watch in German with subtitles

replies.author: @CristalianaIvor
replies.text:
About the Hitler salute being illegal thing:

Many symbolism of the nazi times are banned. For example the Nordic rune "s" as it was used for the SS, the salute, the svastica (outside of educational content that is)...
Modern Nazis just use similar symbols or things that are not outright banned.
For example: alot of number combinations like 88 (stands for the 8th letter in the alphabet, H, twice, it means Heil Hitler = hitler salute), 18 (Adolf Hitler), 28 (Blood and honor) - I think Wikipedia has a list of that?

Also in theory denazification is part of our constitution. Sadly it's not done too a sufficient extent and we have alot of cases rn where they find out that some Nazis were infiltrating the police, ect. I am really scared the right wingers gain too much power again tbh.

But it's also absurd: did you know the fraction leader of the AfD, German nazi party, is a lesbian woman? She's married to an immigrant woman and they live in Switzerland - which is not even part of the EU - so basically she doesn't even live in Germany, but is patriotic? Seriously German politics are a circus show at the moment.

And yes, I think 2015 with the refugee situation this extreme shift to the right got alot of traction. Or maybe it was the first time I realized as I wasn't really into politics much before then.

I feel like we should do alot more awareness about Nazis. But at least we are not like the US who's like... Murdered millions of natives and then goes around telling stories about how they had this cutesy coming together with them celebrating Thanksgiving ðŸ˜…
But I know American education system sucks balls, so I don't blame the citizens...

We try to acknowledge the shit that happened in the past and remind ourselves about what can happen and that we should prevent it from ever happening again.

replies.author: @fivemkelps
replies.text: @CristalianaIvor so, does that mean current nazis can't express their ideologies in anyway apart from those numbers you mentioned? Like they are pressed badly.

replies.author: @CristalianaIvor
replies.text:
@fivemkelps I mean they should not be able to, but they still do. Sadly police is shit about actually doing something against it often...

If you show/use one of the forbidden symbolism you get fined...

But for example: there are neo nazi concerts where they all do hitler salutes but nobody is doing anything...

Also they usually just use flags and stuff that are not banned. Like the German Kaiserreich flag

I discovered JP and his videos on the internet roughly a year a ago and took great interest in what he was saying. What I noticed fairly quickly is how hard he is to critize, but at the same time I know he can't be only right in his words. So I decided that I should always look for things to critize him for since it was fairly easy to do the opposite. For this I have also tried looking for youtubers who can do this without having to distort or strawman his views, which is why I am writing this comment.
You have made an excellent video and you take up great points showing the other side of the argument. You don't misrepresent his views either which is mostly rare for some reason and then keep brining up very valid points on how he is wrong. I found it enjoyable and entertaining to watch and listen to your arguments but most of all it is refreshing to hear somebody being able to properly tell the man where he is probably wrong.

Thank you for having this channel. You've just earned a subscriber and it is fairly few times I do subscribe, even less when I comment!

replies.author: @gastonzumbo9860
replies.text:
@paul1234730 Â Barek ObabaÂ  Mate, minimum wage, work hours, retirement funds, food stamps, etc is all socialism. Social policies are socialist ideas. Socialism isn't "seizing the means of production"; it's government regulation of a country's produce and the distribution of that produce towards the benefit of society at large. It still can work in tandem with the free market and it doesn't completely negate capitalism.

Think of a colour wheel, where you have blue (capitalism) on the left end, red (communism) on the right end, green (fascism) up top and purple (socialism) at the bottom. depending on how close to the center you are, the more government intervention there is, and the conversely, the further away you move from it to each side, the more or less collectivist your government is. And further up or down lies the distribution of power. Where at the top you have the power completely centered around one node of power, as in a dictatorship, and more to the side of purple socialism lies the power of the people. Socialism can never  be a dictatorship. Was Soviet Russia socialist? Fuck no. Was it communist? Yes and no. It had a lot of government intervention but the power still lied within one person. That's not "true communism"; it truly hasn't been tried ever, and likewise, true capitalism has never EVER been put in practice by any society.

The USA isn't full blue. It's between purple and blue, maybe a cyan color if you wanna keep with the colour stuff. Nazi Germany was full on green and Cuba used to be fully purple. North Kore sits between red and green and so forth.

It's simple but, at least i find that it's a good way to do away with the myth that capitalism and socialism are 100% not compatible, that is just not the case.

author: @susischmitt7364
text:
Frankly, you might both be somewhat wrong. Your sources might underestimate the role, nutritition played in the holocaust by stating the (misleading) thought that the Germans were well nourished. This might be true for the Germans, but the Axis-territory as a whole was heavily dependent on soviet imports of food at least since 1940. A quote from 
https://de.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hungerplan#Protokoll_der_Staatssekret%C3%A4re-Besprechung,_2._Mai_1941
translated to English:
"On February, the 14th, Herbert Backe, Secretary of the State explained in the Ministry for Nutrition and Agroeconomy, a 'collapse of the nutrition would occur within the second year of the war, as it did in 1918.'"
From the same page about a document regarding the role of nutrition for the start of the war with the soviets:
"Christian Gerlach has shown in his study of 1999 about the German occupation policy in Belarus, that the document's role for the occupation policy in the Soviet Union was not sufficiently understood."
The document states, that 
"1) The war is only to be continued, if the totality of the German Army can be nourished from Russian Territory within the third year of the war. 
2) Millions of people will perish, if we take from the country, what we need for ourselves."

Long story short: The intention of Hitler might have been to make the Axis independent of food imports from a potential competitor who might like to cut them later on anyways. The trade agreement between Hitler and Stalin at the time states that the Germans mainly imported food and resources, while the Soviets mainly imported advanced parts for military equipment from Germany. Hitler did most likely see this as a sign of military weakness, and thus a good moment to attack. (The Axis' food storage was fading even with soviet imports.)

author: @jakandem
text:
Thanks for the extensive historical analysis! That makes a lot of sense. I really liked the addition of food factor that I haven't heard before.

I think you're projecting a little bit on him when it comes down to your conclusion. I'd agree with almost everything you said up until this point. Nothing he said contradicts the facts you brought in. First thing though, from how I understand what he tried to convey in the video was that psychologically effects of your true beliefs manifests themselves in your actions. He then used the German Nazi ideology manifested by Hitler's decisions where the outlier was that the urge to kill these people was key for the ideology. How does that contradict what you're saying?

You seem to undermine his methodology yet you arrive to a similar conclusion although from different angles. You're saying we should learn about the ideology so we can understand the mechanics. He's saying that we should look at human tendencies from an individualistic perspective that later manifests itself in general. He clearly speaks about how this destructive line of thinking is ingrained to some extent with every individual. These approaches are complimentary and are not mutually exclusive. His is lacking the ideological mechanism, yours is lacking the individual aspect. Now we have both, but how you concluded that he tries to "ascribe Nazi's actions to a wish to cause mayhem" and "we reassure ourselves we can never become them" are a little bit beyond my comprehension.

You're right about the ideology part not being in this lecture but it's not the key factor in what he states initially. He went to great lengths in his other, more recent lectures about consequences of being ideologically possessed for both left and right ends of the spectrum.

Naziism isn't the *only* dangerous and destructive ideology. You can become complicit in evil, and you want to avoid that.

author: @MrMuel1205
text: Jordan Peterson talks about the Enlightenment a lot for someone who peddles so much pseudoscience. And sure, maybe he sees Jungian psychology as a product of the Enlightenment, and in a broad sense it is. But what's important is the Enlightenment isn't some mystical, religious event by which knowledge was bestowed from on high - adoption of reason and science means an ongoing engagement and application of those things. Jungian psychology is pseudoscience - it doesn't arise from a rigorous application of the scientific method. That Peterson continues to clutch onto it shows he has no real commitment to Enlightenment, beyond employing it as a buzzword. You want chaos? Adopt mysticism, adopt Jung, adopt religion - anything can be asserted, anything can be true. You want order? Use the scientific method. Distinguish truth from falsehood.

author: @maxwellschmidt235
text:
A great video.  Peterson's lack of understanding of historical nazis and nazism is likely why he doesn't understand the ways his own views are sympathetic with today's nazis.  Furthermore, he lacks a lot of understanding of military efficiency if he thinks holding prisoners and slaves is less costly than outright murder.  

I can't speak to his psych expertise, the general impression I've gotten from the statements of other professionals is that he seems ok as a practitioner but derivative as an academic.  But in history and political thought, the guy is atrocious.  It's one thing to disagree.  But he makes such caricatured statements about the left resulting in a complete fundamental attribution error.  And his statements on history ignore all facts and the progression of understanding of historical actors. 

If I were to discuss and critique his psychology work, he would rightly tell me that I am unqualified to do so.  He should similarly leave other subjects to their respective practitioners.

@JudeLind Psychologists like Peterson become fundamentalists when their explanation for every kind of human behavior is psychological, which is implicitly to claim that psychology is sufficient to explain everything.  Similarly, religious fundamentalists frequently claim that religion explains everything.  Like Peterson, the religious fundamentalists seldom reference any source of knowledge other than religion.  Peterson's view, like theirs is essentially reductionist and fundamentalist.  Beyond that, in an informal sense the mark of an educated person is how widely  he has read.  It's not clear that Peterson has read anything in history, economics, anthropology, biology, etc.   Peterson is a lowbrow.

I haven't listened to very much of Peterson, because he isn't worth my time, but it's hardly the case that he restricts his opinions to the field of psychology whether or not he does so in any particular video.  An example, is his opinions about the Nazis and Hitler as Three Arrows explains here in detail.

author: @PHSBarrett
text:
Thank you for this very informative video. 
Unfortunately Peterson makes the mistake of trying to fit anything and everything that has ever happened in his worldview. I think it makes it look elegant to people who don't know better. His eloquence is also appealing to most who haven't developed that ability.
Nevertheless it seems to me far-fetched to say that he is peddling in ideas that would result in the kind of ideologies Nazis are involved in. 
He is emphasising the importance of dialogue and negotiation as opposed to what he sees as other ideologically driven individuals who have embedded in their framework the idea of dialogue as a problem, a form of corruption.
I would be more worried about such an ideology resulting in Nazi-like thinking than Peterson's...

I am confused by reading the comments section. A lot of people seem to think that what Peterson says at the end of the video (around 18:00) is that if he talks with the left, then he loses. Peterson: "they regard the idea [some leftists] [...] that if you're in one power group and I'm in another [...] we canÂ´t step out of that group, engage in a dialogue, have our worlds meet, and produce some sort of understanding of [...] of negotiated understanding. No! That's part of [...] your oppressive patriarchal game! That [...] whole idea is part of your game so if I even engage in the dialogue I'm playing your game, you win then."

You can also see that that interpretation is wrong when you see that Peterson has criticised the left for their closeness to dialogue. Honestly, what the fuck is going on here?

author: @truebornseeker9767
text:
Iâ€™ve noticed an argument style from the right:
*compress an idea, then expand it*
Basically; taking an incredibly intricate, complicated topic. Compress it and make it over-simplified (to the point of entirely misrepresenting the topic). Then expand it, use the over-simplified topic to pad out time, add in complicated, logical sounding, big words, pick apart these hugely overly simplistic pixels and further misrepresenting the topic. (These add ons and explanations usually include propaganda)

Some examples of this argument Iâ€™ve seen: â€œgender = sex and those who disagree are against biology and crazyâ€, â€œfeminism is just angry women mad at men because theyâ€™re uglyâ€, â€œcommunism is bad, because countries like Russia and China are â€˜communistâ€™ countriesâ€, â€œBlack lives matter is racist against white people, All lives matter!â€, â€œIf we defund the police, who will you call when youâ€™re being murdered or robber? Blue lives matter!â€, etc

Sometimes itâ€™s done on purpose, but I think, most of the time, itâ€™s a result of assuming everything about a topic from a basic slogan or movement name (an example being Black Lives Matter being taken to mean ONLY black lives matter, or feminism being about FEMales being superior, etc), acting like they know everything about the topic and surrounding their entire opinion around that assumption

author: @e.b.1115
text:
I typed up your conclusions and some responses:


"The reason this is so important is... by understanding that the nazi's actions followed a rationality derived from their basic assumptions about the world, we are able to grasp the destructive force of racist and anti-semitic ideology of a conspiratorial world-view that is centered around the charge of a group wishing to destroy our values, our way of life."


"By simply ascribing the Nazis actions to a wish to cause mayhem to the Mark of Cain, their actions are extraterritorialized from history--exculded from the process of understanding them."


(Peterson never said the nazi's actions were illogical or irrational per se. He said they seemed irrational if your assumption was that their primary goal was to ensure the economic success of the country. 
Their actions were in fact very rational if you assume their primary goal was to exterminate as many Jews and so called gypsies as quickly as possible.)



"If, as Peterson later posits in the video, the cruelties committed by the Nazi perpetrators  are the result of evil or psychopathology, they are excluded from any attempt to understand them as a manifestation of an ideology."


"We can never fully grasp psychopaths, and by pathologizing the perpetrators of the Nazi genocide, we reassure ourselves that we can never become them."


(psychopathology is actually easy to understand if you are familiar with it. The most easily identifiable characteristic is a profound lack of empathy. A point he makes in his video you reference (long version) is that everyone has an "inner psychopath", and it must be harnessed and controlled before it takes you out or takes you over. So, he's definitely NOT saying you simply cannot understand or become Nazis--quite the opposite in fact.)


"Nazism was not just a pathology, and it was not just the result of a want to cause mayhem. Nazis were the result of a concrete worldview"


(The worldview was centered around extremely prejudiced mayhem against certain groups of people. It was not irrational mayhem, and it was indeed founded in a concrete worldview, but it was mayhem nonetheless.)


"If people perceive the world in a way that...


posits that certain behaviors, attitudes, and social positions as primordial


and that people are not interested in talking to you about them or changing them



then conditions brought about by social change, political unrest, or even war, can quickly lead to a political program that, like the Nazis, asserts that the only solution to this problem is for these groups not to live in this world anymore, and to use coercion to assert the natural state of things."



(Assuming this as the solution Jordan is going for to me shows that you don't understand what he is trying to do. 
He does in fact believe there is a rigid faction in the far left that does not want to be reasoned with. 
His plan of action so far has been to talk as much as possible to people NOT in this group, and convince them to engage these culturally imposed belief systems as honestly as possible, developing your own individual take on them. He doesn't say you have to believe exactly what he does.
He's also constantly on about integrating and controlling your darkest urges [including the ones that lead to genocide], so they don't control you. 
If anything, he promotes stoicism or individualism, not authoritarianism.)


If you read this plz feedback:)

author: @inphanta
text:
Good video.  What I find particularly insidious about Peterson is the fact that for months, YouTube has, completely out of nowhere been AGGRESSIVELY recommending his videos to me!  It is clear that whatever algorithms are at play in the serving up of content to users are especially skewed towards content that acts as a gateway to the far right.

My only disagreement with you is that I DO think Peterson is a fascist (of sorts).  He's just acutely aware that openly presenting that way would be counter productive (especially in his line of work), but the fact that his works are so hastily gobbled up by the alt right really says it all.
